Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Situation2: They check a routine prescription for a common cold and confirm the medication matches the label.
Story: I was behind the pharmacy counter, double-checking a prescription for a regular customer. The cold medicine was straightforward, but I always made sure every detail matched the label—accuracy was everything in my job. Just then, my phone buzzed. It was my friend, panicked, saying they were on their way to the airport and thought they’d left their passport at home. “Can you check and bring it to me? I’ll miss my flight otherwise,” they pleaded. I glanced at the clock; the pharmacy was busy, and I was the only pharmacist on duty. My friend needed me—this was an emergency, and I knew how much this trip meant to them. But I also knew that if I left, even for a short while, prescriptions would pile up, and patients would be left waiting. My responsibility to my patients was clear, but so was my loyalty to my friend. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, feeling the tension build as I tried to figure out what to do next.
